Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Chemical sensors for airborne detection
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to enable airborne chemical sensors that are smaller, lighter, and lower cost than existing technology. The devices developed here enable low-power chemical sensing on ultralight drones, in wearable technology, and in small spaces where current technology would not fit or would be prohibitively expensive. The global chemical sensors market, including defense (chemical weapons, explosives), domestic security/first responders (opioids, bomb detection, breath sensors) and industrial hygiene (toxic industrial chemicals) sectors, produces more than $5B in annual revenue, with toxic gas sensors representing $1.5B. This project looks serve markets in the defense, domestic security, and first response sectors due to the size and weight advantages.

This I-Corps project further develops an alternating current impedance technology to detect dielectric changes in custom designed sensor materials. Tuning the probe frequency to target specific chemical interactions allows our sensor to be more selective: For instance, probe frequencies can be chosen to avoid environmental interference, such as water vapor which typically manifests only low-frequency (<100Hz) impedance changes. The method allows greater selectivity with fewer probe elements, allowing simpler devices that can be made smaller, and at lower cost, compared to devices of similar performance. The project incorporates frequency selection into a device that uses an interdigitated capacitor with overlaid thin film of colorimetric material. A microcontroller controls input, feedback, and an impedance analyzer for continuous measurements at targeted frequencies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our team produced market analysis gleaned through customer discovery. Size and funding levels of markets were primary decision-makers for our various pivots. In all sectors, nearly every facet of the chemical sensor (speed, cost, size, weight, selectivity) were always identified as things that could be improved – the primary divider was finding customers who had any funds or administrative interest in purchasing on a scale to warrant a business thesis. Our interviews cleared up these divisions and resulted in our team pivoting away from first responders and industrial safety, and focusing solely on the defense and related homeland security sectors.

 

First Thesis – First Responders. Our initial customer discovery thesis was that a broad market for chemical sensors would exist to assist first responders, given the vast number of fire stations nationwide. Over the course of the program in summer 2019, we performed 113 interviews.  Since summer 2019, another 30 interviews following up the conclusions were performed with the defense industry. The two most important findings were:

 

Finding 1: Not all firefighters have sensors for toxic and industrial chemicals, nor focus on those dangers. Interviewing local firefighters in Tuscaloosa (~100k pop), New York City (~10M pop), and suburban locales in NJ and AL (~30k pop), as well as captains and battalion chiefs, it became obvious that outside of oxygen/CO/H2S/O2/LEL detection, firefighters do not personally carried advanced sensing, limiting greatly the market for VOCs, chemical weapons, explosives, etc. 

 

Finding 2: There is little funding and few purchases for sensing in first response, even for Hazmat and Rescue teams. There simply isn’t much funding available for first response teams for chemical sensors for rare occurrences.  We found a total market value of ~$12M/yr nationwide, compared to the industrial and defense/homeland security sectors.

 

These results convinced our team to pivot to other markets.

 

Second Thesis – Industrial Hygiene. Our new direction follows the larger $30M/yr market for industrial airborne sensing for worker safety.  Our initial hypotheses were that safety compliance officers at companies would have more need for detection solutions, especially if they are less expensive and smaller. However, discussion with government health consultants in three states, as well as compliance solutions consultants, convinced us that this was not the case: Consultants who deal with industrial emergencies (like CTS) have a greater need for improved sensors but are few in number. More importantly, companies day-to-day need only follow OSHA standards by law, which were created in the 1970’s and are a relatively low and easy standard to meet.  As such, companies have almost no motivation to change methods, and actually may increase their own liability by using sensors with detection levels better than required by law. It was suggested that defense and homeland security are the early adopters of chemical sensing technologies, which are then passed down to first response and finally, much later, to industrial safety concerns.

 

Third Thesis – Defense. Our initial thought for this market was that the defense market would be too difficult to penetrate. To test this, we interviewed DOD and DHS Joint Program Managers, who are in charge of innovation funding for new chemical sensing technologies, testing, and potential deployment and purchasing.  They suggested that Other Transaction Agreements, or OTAs, are a great way for small businesses to work with defense, as program managers are quite interested in new ideas and willing to fund exploratory “Phase 0” and prototyping “Phase 1 and 2” contracts prior to orders. Additionally, the market is extraordinarily big: Phase 1 contracts in chemical sensing exceed $140M/yr alone. Although the field requires larger Customer Acquisition Costs due to him conference travel, meetings with program managers, and consortium efforts, we found that, due to the large Phase 1 contract sizes ($200-750k/yr), making phase 1 contracts alone give a LTV/CAC value of ~12, financially viable but with higher risk due to the lower numbers of customers.

 

Within the defense sector, lowering unit costs was not nearly as important as lowering size, weight, and power consumption, and getting the best sensitivity and selectivity humanly possible. The cost per device for our potential product was many times lower than the threshold amount for a product to be considered a one-use product.

 

Conclusion. Our customer discovery disproved two potential markets (Industrial Hygiene, First Responders) and identified the Defense OTA market as a lucrative market. Defense contracting requires long-term time commitment but offers excellent CAC/LTV with minimal risk and cash outlay.

 

II. Prototype Development

 

In this project we were able to create a small wireless sensor prototype.  The device is 1” by 1.2” in size and can measure three sensor materials in parallel.  In addition, we are developing an IoT application to make networked chemical sensing a reality.  These attributes are based on desired capabilities stated by DOD OTA PMs during our customer discovery phase.
